oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Jenkins home in Rutherford County
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Rutherford County Historical Society Publication No. 19
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 59 THE JENKINS HOMES in RUTHERFORD COUNTT by- Rosalind Manson James A WILL probated in Greene Coun-ty, Ohio, 11 November 1807 (quote) "Item 5, I give to n^ sons Hiram Jenkins and Nij&rod Jenkins nineteen htmdred and twenty acres of land in the State of Tennessee to be divided in the same manner that I directed it lAen I was there, ex-clTisive of what they have had, to them and to their heirs and assigns forever. October U, l807" signed/Aaron Jenkins This WILL of 1920 acres really started the fun! Where did Aaron who was only a private in John Guthray's Class Roll (c) First Battalion Washington County, Pa MLlltia during the Revolution, get this Tennessee property? Well, since I960 there have been "cousins" from Los Angeles, California; Fbrtsmouth, Ohio; Mocha Bend, Mlsso\iri; Harrisburg, Pa. and me here in Rutherford County searching for verification of that bequest. The court house has been beseiged and volumes of records copied and all has been enjoyed. I have found that we "Jenkinses" are numerous and inquisitive. We have docTznentation of ptirchase liy the inmigrants of property in Pa. and Virginia since 1752 so the "cousins" came to document the Tennessee property. We took them to see "Marymont" and from that beautiful antebellum home which is still in the family and from this they "advertized" to all interested "cousins" arotmd the country. What they didn't know until they toured the county and copied wills and coiirt records of the ntinerous law suits at the Cotrt House Just how the beautiful "Marymont" evolved. 60 The stoxy Is slnple- For Revolutionary service Aaron II (Aaron I was from Frederick County, Virginia) received 610 acres for service and probably bought adjoining grants. "In 1799 Aaron and his wife Rebecca Baldwin Jenkins and five of their children moved from Pettis County, Missouri settling on Stones River near Murfreesboro in Rutherford County. Rebecca died enroute 17 May 1799 and was buried at Crab Orchard, Kentucky. Aaron returned to Pennsylvania and married Charity Harlan Garwood, a Quakeress. During his absence, his sons killed and assisted in killing fifty-two bears. In vhLch the country greatly abounded." "In 180U, Aaron and Charity with their famlly-wlth the exception of sons, Hiram and Nimrod, returned to Ohio to land purchased in 1799 from Albert Gallatin." It was Nimrod and Ifi.ram who built the first Jenkins house on the northeast part of the "Marymont" property. It is still staisdlng (just off the lane leading to the old Klngwood property). The two large rooms were well built of brick with good features of deep window slUs, large twelve paned windows, a chimney at each end, and a porch across the front with small round pillars. A story is told in the family of how one night a rec\irrent dream disturbed Nimrod so he got ip and went back to where there was a very deep spring and there burled their hoard of gold. When he returned to the house he found that thieves had ransacked the place. This house was the beginning of a series of fine Jenkins homes in otir community. Nimrod never married but his brother Hiram I married Deborah Allison, ( Davidson County Marriage Book), May 31> I803. Since Ruther-ford County was created from Davidson County in I803 they probably 61 Married here. He built his hams an the Hanson Pike (then not named perhaps) and there reared a large family. That house burned and the old graveyard was destroyed but I rescued two tall marble markers from Mr. Martindale's bam (later owned b7 Frank Wanack) and had these placed in the Jenkins lot in Evergreen Cemetery. They marked the graves of Hiram Jenkins, Jr. who was bom in Fayette County, Peimsylvania, February 21 , 1780 and moved to Tennessee in the year 1797 and died 10 October 1857. "Blessed are the pure in Hart for they shall see God" (and the other) In memory of Nimrod Jenkins Bom in Pettis Co, MLssourl Septr. 22 1822 Died in Rtitherford Co. Tenn Dec 13 1855 Nimrod Jenkins was united in marriage with Jane W. Moore of Rutherford Co., Jan 18, l85U and closed his earthly career Dec 13, 1855 "Blessed are the dead which die in the Lord from henceforth Yes saith the spirit they may rest from their labor and their works do follow them. Nimrod I never married. He left a WILL which caused many lawsuits (see Rutherford County court records) . But ny ancestor Nimrod II (named for his uncle) married January l8, l85ii-Jane Woodson Moox« and they had two daughters. Mazy Jane (Jenny) and Nimmie (named for her father iriio had died shortly before her birth). He had built a house, however, on the Jenkins property which he had inherited across the lane (later named Gresham Lane) from his father's place on Ihe Manson Pike. After his death '*Mlttie," as she was called married Captain Amossa Gresham and 62 Original Jenkins home built about iSO? on "Marymount " property om Rucker lane. James Jenkins home on IVIanson Pike built by Hiram Jenkins Sr. and owned by Robert Martindale in I969. 63 there they reared their large family. This home was used duxdng the Battle of Stone's River as a hospital and was known as the "Greshan Place.'* This hone remained in the family until in the early 1930*s» ^en it was sold to Mr. Allen Ragland. Ownership changed se-veral times, it burned, and now among the large oaks and maple trees is a modem brick home owned by Mr. Thomas Lane. Another Jenkins home was almost directly across from the Gresham place and also the Frank Womack place (fozner Hiram Jenkins hone, identical in architecture to the Nimrod Jenkins place) was Jennie Jenkins Manson's place. It was a typical Victorian home with tall windows across the front and a vestibule style entry. Ceilings were high, rooms were large and the "parlor" had a black marble mantel and black iron fireplace. Around the high walls were enlarged family photographs. This home also is gone, the interstate intersects the property and another land mark is gone. A smaller, but sturdy brick house down the road toward the city of Murfreesboro still stands, a pretty Jenkins home. Hiram Jenkins II gave his dau^ter Alice Jenkins this home when she married Mr. H. H. Kerr, but when she died in 1870 he sold it. It reminds us however, that homes built sturdily, thou^ stonas and disasters came, they remain - as the first Jenkins two-room house on "Marymont" property, the Hiram or James Jenkins house on Manson Fike, and "MarTmont" itself. "Marymont" was built by Hiram Jenkins II (brother of Nimrod H) and his wife Nancy Puckett while he was guaztlian for the infant dau^ters of Nimrod, Jennie and Nimnde. This is on the other end of the Jenkins property and was the property inherited by Niimie Jenkins who married Dr. James J. Rucker, and was named for their only surviving child, Mary. It was greatly embellished about the time of Mary's marriage to R. E. Donnell 64 ly the addition of the Corinthian columns. All of the children of the fasUy Uked to visit there and ride Dr. Rucker's horses and see and lay around the deer park kept by Dr. Ruoker for Mary. It still stands and Is a reminder to us to protect and preserve. May we always keep alive our Interest In our Jenkins «cou8lns" and always cqspreclate what our forbears did to enrich our lives and the lives of our progeny. 65 Dr. James E. I^lanson son James E. I/lansons home on Manson Pike. House now gone and site occupied by Bascom Williamson house. Jennie Jenkins Manson , Virginia Bagwell & Findley Hudgens are in the picture. The Jenkins home on the Manson pike & Gresham lane. In the field v/as the former home of Hiram 1 .It burned. 66 Jenkins - Gresham house on T/Ianson Pike. Built about 1^50 & usee as a hospital in Battle of Stones River. Maryraount- Home of Mary Rucker Donnell. Built about lS6l by Hiram Jenkins on Rucker Lane
A history of the Jenkins home, "Marymont"
